column1: This framework was designed by Utkarsh to solve the problem of tracking effort accurately.
Previously, we estimated in weeks which didn't translate well to sprint planning.
By using days (1 SP = 1 working day), we get:
1. Clear visibility into where time goes
3. Data-driven retros showing why spillover happens

column2: 1 SP = 1 working day of effort for 1 person
column3: If a task takes 3 days for 1 dev, it's 3 SP

column2: Business days in a cycle, excluding weekends
Working days minus leaves and on-call deductions
column4: What a person can actually commit to

column2: Planned initiative work from quarterly roadmap
Unplanned work: bugs, support, cross-pod requests
column3: Prod hotfix, PR reviews, other pod support

column2: Total effort allocated to a project for the quarter
column3: Communication Module = 60 BE days for Q1

column2: Work committed but not completed in sprint
column3: Committed 50 SP, completed 40 SP = 10 SP spillover

column1: Step 1: Start with gross working days
- Check leave calendar for each team member
WHY: On-call engineers can't commit 100% to roadmap work
- Primary On-Call: 40% time on incidents = 4 SP deduction
- Backup On-Call: 20% time on support = 2 SP deduction
- We have 4 on-call roles (2 BE + 2 FE) = 12 SP total deduction
FORMULA: Available SP = Working Days - Leaves - On-Call Deduction
Based on historical data and team feedback:
- 60% is realistic for planned roadmap work
- 40% covers the reality of engineering work:
- On-call incident response (already deducted but buffer helps)

column5: Bugs, support, PR reviews, unplanned work

column1: Why split by BE/FE: Ensures we don't over-commit one skill type
On-call engineers must be available for production incidents.
They cannot commit 100% of their time to roadmap work.
Deduction percentages based on historical incident data:
- Primary: ~40% of time goes to incidents/monitoring
- Backup: ~20% of time goes to supporting primary
1. Each initiative gets a Q1 budget in days (from roadmap planning)
2. Each sprint, we commit SP to that initiative
3. Committed SP deducts from the initiative budget
4. We track 'Remaining' to see if we're on pace
Data-Driven Cohorts: 10 BE days budget for Q1
- Shows early if an initiative is behind schedule
- Helps prioritize when capacity is limited

column3: Every dev spends ~1 day/sprint on code reviews
Requests from Platform, GTS, other teams
Urgent production issues that can't wait

column1: 1. Don't pre-assign all adhoc SP at sprint start
3. If adhoc exceeds 42 SP, roadmap work will spill
4. Review in retro: was 40% enough? Too much?
1. Add all committed tickets at sprint start
2. Update status daily or every 2 days
3. Mark 'Completed?' as Yes when ticket is Done
- Blocked: Waiting on dependency or another team
- Underestimation: Task was bigger than expected
- Priority Change: Pulled to work on something else

column3: How much of what we promised did we deliver?
How much work didn't get done?
Are we using our capacity well?

column2: Completed Roadmap SP / Committed Roadmap SP × 100
column3: Are we hitting our initiative commitments?

column1: - 80% Delivery Rate: Allows for unknowns while being accountable
- <10 SP Spillover: Small spillover is normal, large means planning issues
- >90% Utilization: Under 90% means we're not committing enough

column2: Create tickets in Linear with SP labels
Track adhoc work that comes in
